title: Tennis Vocabulary
description: Serve up your knowledge of tennis terms and lingo!

questions.question: In tennis, what is a 'let'?
options: A fault on the second serve
A volley hit from behind the baseline
A serve that clips the net but lands in the correct service box, requiring a replay
A point won without the opponent touching the ball
questions.explanation: A let occurs when a serve touches the net cord but still lands in the correct service box. The serve is replayed without penalty.

questions.question: What does 'deuce' mean in tennis scoring?
options: The score is 30-30
The score is tied at 40-40
The second set of the match
A double fault
questions.explanation: Deuce in tennis means the score is tied at 40-40. A player must win two consecutive points from deuce to win the game.

questions.question: In tennis, what is a 'drop shot'?
options: A shot hit from behind the body
A serve that drops below the net
A shot that bounces twice before the opponent reaches it
A softly hit shot that lands just over the net
questions.explanation: A drop shot is a softly struck ball designed to barely clear the net and land close to it, catching an opponent who is positioned far back.

questions.question: What is an 'ace' in tennis?
options: A shot hit down the middle of the court
A serve that the opponent cannot return at all
The first point of a tie-break
Winning a game without losing a point
questions.explanation: An ace is a legal serve that is not touched by the receiver, resulting in a point for the server. It is often hit with great speed or placement.

questions.question: In tennis, what does 'break of serve' mean?
options: Winning a game when the opponent is serving
A pause during the server's motion
A serve that breaks the strings
The interval between sets
questions.explanation: A break of serve occurs when the receiving player wins the game against the server, which is significant because the server has a natural advantage.

questions.question: What is a 'topspin' shot in tennis?
options: A shot where the ball spins backward, staying low
A lob hit high into the air
A shot where the ball spins forward, dipping quickly after crossing the net
A shot that floats without any spin
questions.explanation: Topspin is forward rotation on the ball, created by brushing up on it. It causes the ball to dip sharply and bounce high, a key weapon in modern tennis.

questions.question: In tennis, what is a 'bagel'?
options: Winning a set 6-0
A round tournament trophy
A circular motion in the serve
A ball that spins in a circle
questions.explanation: A 'bagel' is slang for winning a set 6-0, because the zero resembles the shape of a bagel. A 'double bagel' means winning both sets 6-0.

questions.question: What is the 'no-man's land' in tennis?
options: The area between the baseline and the service line
The space directly under the net
The area outside the court lines
The area between the doubles and singles sidelines
questions.explanation: No-man's land is the area between the baseline and the service line, considered a vulnerable position because balls bounce at the player's feet.

questions.question: In tennis, what is a 'volley'?
options: A shot hit from behind the baseline
Hitting the ball before it bounces
A rally of more than ten shots
The opening shot of a game
questions.explanation: A volley is a shot made by hitting the ball before it bounces on the court, typically executed near the net.

questions.question: What is a 'Grand Slam' in tennis?
options: Winning a match without losing a single game
Winning any four tournaments in a year
Winning three sets in a row
Winning all four major tournaments in a calendar year
questions.explanation: A Grand Slam in tennis means winning all four major championships (Australian Open, French Open, Wimbledon, US Open) in the same calendar year.

questions.question: In tennis, what does 'advantage' mean?
options: Serving from the preferred side
Having a higher ranking
Leading by two sets
The point scored immediately after deuce
questions.explanation: Advantage is the point scored immediately after deuce (40-40). The player who wins this point has the 'advantage' and needs one more point to win the game.

questions.question: What is a 'passing shot' in tennis?
options: A shot played between the legs
A shot that passes just over the net
A groundstroke hit past an opponent who is at the net
A serve that passes the opponent
questions.explanation: A passing shot is a groundstroke hit past an opponent who has come to the net, either down the line or cross-court, out of their reach.

questions.question: In tennis, what is a 'tweener'?
options: A match played between two teenagers
A ball landing on the line
A tie-break between sets
A shot hit between the legs while running away from the net
questions.explanation: A tweener (or 'hotdog') is a trick shot hit between the player's legs, usually while running away from the net to retrieve a lob.

questions.question: What does 'double fault' mean in tennis?
options: Missing both the first and second serve
Two errors in a single rally
Two consecutive lets on a serve
Being penalized twice in one game
questions.explanation: A double fault occurs when a server fails to get either the first or second serve into play, resulting in the loss of that point.

questions.question: In tennis, what is a 'lob'?
options: A short forehand slice
A shot hit high into the air, intended to sail over an opponent at the net
A serve hit with backspin
A rally that lasts fewer than three shots
questions.explanation: A lob is a high-arcing shot intended to sail over the head of an opponent positioned at the net, either defensively to buy time or offensively to win the point.
